ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a comprehensive understanding of ritual theory and applications, and most importantly, knowledge of a diverse array of reputable ritual scholarship beginning from the 19th century.
A much broader and stronger understanding of the foundational concepts in religious studies surrounding rituals.
I learned a lot about ritual, how different scholars think about ritual, and its role, function, nature and character, etc. See the syllabus for a more specific overview of topics.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the diversity of the readings was great, and I appreciated how each reading material worked off the readings from previous weeks, and culminated in Rappaport's ritual theory. I wish some chapters in Rappaport were cut out.
The course was a lot of fun, and coming out the other side I really feel like I've gotten a stronger grasp of what religious studies is all about, and why it's important.

Even though they were my weekly nightmare to write, the 500-750 word reading responses were very helpful. Now that I have them I am very happy I wrote them, and they were very useful for the final paper. I appreciated Professor Greene's comments on them; instead of just giving a grade, he would go through them and note where I had the right idea and where I may have misunderstood something. I learned from that too. I must say that the reading was very long and very dense for the class. I will also note that for students who prefer to use dictation for whatever reason, almost none of the PDFs are dictation compatible, which for me meant many additional hours of reading by hand.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Greene, I appreciate you being flexible and adjusting workload and class time to our needs during this pandemic.

Professor Greene ran a great class, and I'd say on zoom we made good use of the chat in addition to being a small class able to have a conversation. One suggestion I would have is to give the 5min break in the middle. Two hours straight on zoom is a very long time, and I think we would have benefitted from just a brief respite.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would not unless they are someone not majoring in religious studies but still hold a strong interest in the major. Religious studies majors are supposed to take this course, and though it is a rigorous course I would "recommend" this to anyone who is willing to take a class that is challenging but also very fruitful.

Absolutely. What an awesome major requirement. I really feel like I've gotten a stronger grasp of what religious studies is all about, and why it's important. The weekly reading responses can take some time, but they do contribute to understanding. This course would be even more fun in person!

I would recommend. It is required for RLST students, so tough for you. The benefit is that you get to meet all the other RLST students in your year, which is cool. But for everyone else, I would recommend reviewing the syllabus and seeing if the topics interest you! My class did have a student who was not RLST, and it is absolutely worthwhile for students who have an interest in the subject and just want to take the course as an elective. I thought this year's topicritualwas a really great one. Professor Greene really gives a lot of free reign to apply the material to subjects of interest in class and in our reading responses and papers (for me this meant military customs and rituals), and these do not have to be overtly religious or associated with a religion (again, I was focused on the military).

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
